Glioma.short_description: A type of tumor that occurs in the brain and spinal cord, originating from glial cells.
Glioma.detailed_description: Gliomas are tumors that arise from glial cells, which support and protect neurons in the brain. They can be slow-growing (low-grade) or aggressive (high-grade). Symptoms vary based on location but may include headaches, seizures, and neurological changes.
Glioma.prevalence: Most common primary brain tumor in adults
Glioma.educational_note: Early detection and characterization are important for treatment planning.

Meningioma.short_description: A typically benign tumor that arises from the meninges, the membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord.
Meningioma.detailed_description: Meningiomas are usually slow-growing tumors that develop from the meninges. Most are benign (non-cancerous), though some can be atypical or malignant. They may cause symptoms by pressing on nearby brain tissue.
Meningioma.prevalence: Second most common primary brain tumor
Meningioma.educational_note: Many meningiomas grow slowly and may only require monitoring.

No Tumor.short_description: No tumor detected in the brain MRI scan.
No Tumor.detailed_description: The scan shows normal brain anatomy without evidence of tumor. This is a healthy brain scan showing expected structures and tissue patterns.
No Tumor.educational_note: This result indicates no tumor is visible in the scan. Always consult with a healthcare provider for complete evaluation.

Pituitary.short_description: A tumor in the pituitary gland, a small gland at the base of the brain that produces hormones.
Pituitary.detailed_description: Pituitary tumors (adenomas) are usually benign growths in the pituitary gland. They can affect hormone production, leading to various endocrine symptoms. Most are non-cancerous but may require treatment if causing symptoms.
typical_characteristics: May affect optic chiasm if large
Pituitary.educational_note: Pituitary tumors are often treatable with medication, surgery, or radiation.
